and it indicates once again that this
this unrest that is being driven by

borders of Egypt in Egypt the military
and protest organizers are forming a new
alliance it's two days after the ouster
of President Hosni Mubarak and the
question on the minds of many in the
opposition and in Tahrir Square the
center of the revolution is just how
serious is the military that's taken
over this country about steering it
towards democracy the military leaders
met for the first time with a group of
civilians from the opposition a group of
the young leaders the revolution and
they laid out a very brisk timetable for
a transition to democracy they're
talking
about 10 days for proposing
constitutional amendments two months for
a referendum to approve those Amendment
and then six months for an election for
a new Parliament new president the whole
thing and there's some debate within the
opposition over is that enough time is
it enough time for parties to get
established it's enough time for
candidates to get their messages out or
is it going to be a situation where
somebody wins just in the basis of name
recognition and beyond that there's a
question of just how serious the
military is so far they've had this one
meeting that they don't seem inclined to
meet with the Nobel Prize winning
diplomat Mohamed ElBaradei who is the
chosen negotiator of the opposition and
while they're meeting with civilians
they haven't yet brought anyone from the
opposition into their ranks into the
process of governing at the same time
the military issued their sixth
communicated today asking people to get
back to work because there are still a
lot of wildcat strikes around the
country people asking for more money in
the aftermath of the revolution my
colleague Steve Farrell checked in on
the all-important tourism industry
region this church is on sale for twelve
dollars in Cairo already although the
revolutionary slogans have barely been
scrubbed from the walls of Tahrir Square
Egypt's tourist economy has been
devastated since the January 25th
revolution the pyramids usually packed
are now virtually deserted five-star
hotels lie empty and tour companies have
lost a fortune because of cancellations
and postponements we have lost average
average about three and half four
million dollars mr. Nazeri was sitting

accounts for eleven percent of its gross

percent of egypt's foreign currency
